newsitem.title: GREECE: Alpha Credit Bank says H1 pretax up 56.1pct y/y.
newsitem.headline: Alpha Credit Bank says H1 pretax up 56.1pct y/y.

text.p: Alpha Credit Bank, Greece's largest private bank, said in a statement its half-year pretax profit rose 56.1 percent year-on-year to 42.3 billion drachmas from 27.07 billion a year earlier.
On a consolidated basis, pretax earnings before minorities grew 54 percent to 54.7 billion drachmas in the first half of 1997 compared to the respective period of 1996, it said.
The bank did not release interim figures on its profit after minorities which was 30.8 billion drachmas in the first half of 1996.

Total assets amounted to 3.07 trillion drachmas as of end-June 1997, up 35.6 percent year-on-year, while on a consolidated basis total assets grew 36 percent to 3.253 billion drachmas, Alpha Credit Bank said.
On the same date, deposits stood at 2.021 trillion drachmas -- up 15.7 percent year-on-year.
Loans rose 34.1 percent to 2.021 trillion over the year to end-June.
Total shareholders' funds increased 76.7 percent year-on-year to 212 billion drachmas, boosted by the April-May 1997 share capital increase.
Consolidated book value was up 63 percent to 245.7 billion drachmas. --Angelos Kiosklis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
